title: Why Are Testing Rates Going Down?
description:
Testing is down 40% in two of the hardest-hit states — Texas and Florida. Ashish Jha of Harvard's Global Health Institute explains what might be going on.

NPR's Alison Aubrey describes a new COVID-19 test developed by Yale University that works with saliva.

And NPR's Kirk Sielger reports on a school district in Idaho that's preparing to reopen — and possibly close right back down again.

Find and support your local public radio station.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

itunes:title: Why Are Testing Rates Going Down?
itunes:author: NPR
itunes:summary: The U.S. is averaging fewer COVID-19 tests each day than it was a few weeks ago. With test results taking too long to be useful, doctors may be ordering less.
itunes:subtitle: The U.S. is averaging fewer COVID-19 tests each day than it was a few weeks ago. With test results taking too long to be useful, doctors may be ordering less.
